topic_seeds.description: Struggling with social situations and fear of judgment
Feeling like a fraud despite achievements (relatively straightforward)
Seeking diagnosis or medication guidance (complex, layered situation)

exchanges.user:
Hey. So I've been meaning to reach out for a while now, honestly. Things have just been... complicated lately, and I'm not really sure where to start.

Work has been the main thing eating at me. I'm in this weird position where I've been successful, relatively speaking. Made decent money, solid track record, the kind of resume that looks good on paper. But there's this constant voice in my head telling me I've somehow fooled everyone into thinking I'm competent when really I'm just getting lucky. It's exhausting, if I'm being honest.

And then there's the social stuff. I went to this work function last month and just felt completely out of place the entire time. Everyone seemed so comfortable, making small talk, laughing at jokes. I was just standing there thinking about what they might be judging me for. I know intellectually that most people are too caught up in their own heads to care, but knowing that and believing it are two different things, you know?

The career thing is also tied up with finances. I've had some opportunities to pivot into something less lucrative but maybe more fulfilling, and I keep going back and forth on whether I'm being irresponsible or whether I'm just letting fear make my decisions for me. My family's expecting me to keep doing what I'm doing, which doesn't help.

Anyway, I'm rambling. But yeah, those are the main things. Not sure if you can even help with any of this, but figured it was worth trying.
exchanges.assistant:
I'm glad you reached out. That took something—especially when you're not sure where to start or if it'll even help.

**The imposter thing at work:** That gap you're describing—between what looks true on paper and what feels true in your head—is one of the most common patterns I see, especially in people who actually are competent. The voice saying "you've fooled everyone" is loud, but here's what I'm curious about: when you've delivered on projects or solved problems at work, what do you think actually happened? Like, if it wasn't competence, what was it? I'm not asking rhetorically—I genuinely want to know what your mind says when you try to explain your own track record.

**The work function:** Standing there watching everyone else seem comfortable while you're cataloging what they might be judging you for—that's rough. You're right that knowing people aren't focused on you and actually feeling it are different. What do you think you were most worried they were judging? And has there ever been a social situation where that self-consciousness was quieter, even a little?

**The career crossroads:** This tension between the "safe" path your family expects and the thing that might actually feel right—that's not a small thing. You're asking whether you're being irresponsible or just scared, and honestly, it might be both. Or neither. What does the part of you that wants to pivot know that the part of you staying put doesn't want to hear?

You said you're not sure I can help. Fair. But you showed up anyway, which tells me some part of you thinks it's worth trying. What would "help" even look like for you?

exchanges.user:
So I've been sitting with what you asked me, and honestly it's been kind of gnawing at me in a way I didn't expect.

The imposter thing—when I actually try to point to specific projects or wins, it gets harder to dismiss them as pure luck. There was this system redesign I led two years ago that actually did improve things measurably. My team members cite it. Clients noticed. But my brain's immediate response is "yeah but that was just because the timing was right" or "I had good people around me." Which is true, I did, but... I don't know. Maybe that's just how work actually works and I'm holding myself to some impossible standard where I should've succeeded entirely on my own or something. Weird when you say it out loud like that.

The social thing is still there though. Actually had another situation yesterday at a team lunch. Someone cracked a joke and I laughed but it felt performative even as I was doing it. Like I'm always a half-second behind everyone else, playing catch-up in conversations. I don't think anyone noticed anything weird, but that's almost worse because it means I'm the only one feeling this distance, which makes it feel more real somehow.

On the career thing—I haven't really talked to my wife about the pivot option yet. I know I should. There's this part of me that knows she'd probably be more supportive than I'm assuming, but bringing it up feels like admitting I'm unhappy with the path we've been on, and I don't know if I want to have that conversation right now. Does that make sense? Or am I just avoiding it?
exchanges.assistant:
**The imposter thing—what you just noticed:** You caught something important: your brain's reflex is to hand credit to timing and other people, but when you actually look at the project, there's your leadership, your design work, measurable results. The "impossible standard where I should've succeeded entirely on my own"—yeah, that's the trap. No one works that way. Collaboration isn't evidence against competence; it's how competent people get things done. What happens if you let yourself take credit for assembling the right people and making good calls on timing? Does that feel different than "I got lucky"?

**The half-second delay at lunch:** That feeling of being performative even when you're genuinely laughing—I hear you. It's like you're watching yourself from outside, evaluating whether you're doing it right, which makes everything feel distant. You're right that no one else noticed, but I don't think that makes the distance more real. I think it means the distance is between you and your own experience, not between you and other people. What would it be like to just... let the laugh happen without the commentary track running? Not saying that's easy, but I'm curious what gets in the way.

**Not talking to your wife yet:** That makes complete sense. Bringing it up feels like opening a door you're not sure you want to walk through—admitting dissatisfaction with the current path, risking her reaction, maybe disappointing her. But here's what I'm noticing: you said she'd "probably be more supportive than I'm assuming." That probably is doing a lot of work. What's the assumption you're operating on right now? And where does it come from—something she's said, or something your mind is filling in?

exchanges.user:
Been a rough few days, honestly. Work has been intense—we had this client call that went sideways, and of course my first instinct was to think it was entirely my fault, even though my manager explicitly said it wasn't a messaging problem on our end. They said the client came in with unrealistic expectations. But I still spent two hours replaying the call in my head looking for where I could've done better.

The thing about my wife though—I actually did bring it up. Not in the way I was planning to, just sort of... happened over dinner. I was venting about how exhausted I am, and she just looked at me and asked directly if I was thinking about leaving. Caught me off guard. Turns out she's known for months that something's been off. She wasn't upset about the idea of a pivot, but she did ask some practical questions about savings, timeline, all the responsible stuff. Which makes sense, but also now there's this actual conversation happening that I can't just think about in the abstract anymore.

And separately—I had lunch with an old friend yesterday who I haven't seen in like a year. It was easy. Natural. No performance, no half-second delay. We just fell back into talking the way we always do. Which made me realize something: the distance thing at work isn't universal. I don't feel it with everyone. So maybe it's not that I'm inherently off, maybe it's the specific environment or specific people. Though I'm not sure if that's helpful or just moving the goalposts on myself.

Anyway. Things are moving whether I want them to or not.
exchanges.assistant:
**The client call spiral:** Two hours replaying a call your manager already told you wasn't your fault—that's the imposter pattern we've been tracking, but sharper this time. Your manager named the actual problem (unrealistic client expectations), and your brain still went hunting for your mistake. What I'm curious about is: when you were replaying it, did you actually find anything concrete you'd change? Or was it more like scanning for a feeling of "this must be wrong somewhere"?

**The conversation with your wife:** That's a big shift. She's known for months, she wasn't upset, and now it's real—not abstract anymore. That mix of relief (she already knew, she's not angry) and oh shit (now we're actually talking timelines and savings) makes complete sense. Her practical questions aren't rejection; they're her way of taking it seriously. But I'm hearing some anxiety in "I can't just think about it in the abstract anymore." What's scary about it being real? Is it the accountability, the finality, something else?

**The lunch with your old friend:** This is actually huge. No performance, no delay, just easy. You felt present. That tells you the distance isn't baked into who you are—it's context-dependent. You're wondering if that's just "moving the goalposts," but I don't think so. I think it's data. What's different about your old friend versus the work lunch crowd? Is it familiarity, stakes, the kind of conversation, how much you trust them?

Things are moving whether you want them to or not. Yeah. That's both the terrifying part and maybe the part that gets you unstuck.

exchanges.user:
So I've been thinking about what you asked—about whether I actually found anything concrete to change in that client call. Honest answer is no. I was just... looking for the mistake because it felt like there had to be one. My brain wouldn't let it go even though logically I knew better.

Work's been a bit better since then, weirdly. Or maybe I'm just distracted by the other stuff.

The bigger thing is the conversation with my wife has kind of spiraled in the best and worst way at the same time. We started talking about timelines and what a pivot would actually look like financially, and she brought up the idea of me taking a sabbatical first—like, actually stepping away for a few months to figure out what I actually want instead of just reacting to how exhausted I am. Part of me thinks that's brilliant. The other part is already doing the math on whether we can afford it and whether it's irresponsible and whether I'd just spend three months in my own head spiraling instead of actually figuring anything out.

But here's the thing that's been bugging me since our last conversation. You asked what's different about my old friend versus the work people. And I realized I trust him way more. Like, he knows all my failures and weird shit and he doesn't care. At work, I'm always aware that people are evaluating me—for competence, for whether I should be leading, whatever. Even though most of it is probably in my head. So it's not that I'm broken in social situations generally. It's that I'm hypervigilant about judgment in environments where judgment actually matters for my career. Which when I write it out sounds obvious, but it also feels kind of defeating because I can't just stop caring what my colleagues think of me.
exchanges.assistant:
**The client call pattern you named:** You were looking for the mistake because it felt like there had to be one—not because you found one. That's the loop in its purest form. Your brain needed to locate fault even when your manager already cleared you. The fact that you can see that now, that you caught yourself scanning for a *feeling* rather than actual evidence—that's not small. That's the gap between what your anxiety insists must be true and what's actually there.

**The sabbatical idea:** Your wife suggesting you step away to figure out what you actually want instead of just reacting to exhaustion—that's a really generous way to frame it. And your brain immediately went to: can we afford it, is it irresponsible, will I just spiral for three months. Those aren't unreasonable questions, but here's what I'm noticing: the "irresponsible" voice sounds a lot like the voice that won't let you take credit for the system redesign. What if taking time to get clear on what you want isn't irresponsible—what if it's the opposite? What would three months look like if you weren't just "in your own head spiraling"? Like, what would you actually *do* with that time if you trusted yourself to use it well?

**What you realized about trust and hypervigilance:** You nailed it. With your friend, there's no performance because there's no stakes—he knows your mess and he's still there. At work, you're tracking for judgment because judgment actually has consequences for your career and identity. That's not broken. That's your brain doing threat detection in an environment where the threats are real, even if they're not as constant as your vigilance suggests. But here's the part that might be worth sitting with: you said "I can't just stop caring what my colleagues think of me," and you're right. You can't and you shouldn't. But there's a difference between *caring* what they think and *assuming* they're judging you negatively by default. What if most of your colleagues aren't evaluating you the way you're evaluating yourself? What if their bar for "competent enough" is way lower than yours?

exchanges.user:
Quick update before I forget—had this moment yesterday that I keep turning over in my head.

We were in a meeting, and I made a suggestion about how to restructure a workflow. Someone pushed back, said it wouldn't work, gave reasons. My immediate reaction was this hot flush of shame, like I'd just revealed myself as incompetent in front of everyone. But then someone else in the room said "actually, I think Arjun's onto something" and suddenly the conversation shifted. We ended up going with a modified version of my idea.

The weird part is I *knew* logically that pushback on ideas is just how meetings work. But I felt so relieved when someone validated it, like I'd been holding my breath the whole time and finally got permission to exhale. Which makes me sound like I have zero confidence, I guess. I don't know. It's not like I doubt my competence in the abstract—when I'm heads down on actual work, I'm fine. It's the visibility thing that gets to me. Being seen doing the work versus having done the work are apparently very different for me.

On the sabbatical thing—we're actually talking about it more concretely now. My wife found some budget cushion we didn't think we had, which helps. But now I'm in this weird space where it actually *could* happen, and that's making me anxious in a different way than the abstract "should I do this" anxiety. More like... if I actually do this, what if I spend three months and come out the other side and realize I don't want to change anything? Or worse, realize I've been running from the wrong thing the whole time?

Anyway. Things feel like they're shifting. Not sure if it's progress or just different problems yet.
exchanges.assistant:
**The meeting moment—that hot flush of shame:** That reaction when someone pushed back wasn't about the idea itself, it was about what you thought the pushback meant about *you*. That split second of "I've been exposed as incompetent" before the conversation even finished—that's the hypervigilance we've been tracking. And then the relief when someone validated you wasn't just "good, my idea works," it was "good, I'm safe again." You're right that pushback is just how meetings work, but your nervous system is reading it as a referendum on whether you belong in the room at all.

Here's what stands out though: you said when you're heads down on actual work, you're fine. It's the *visibility* that activates the threat response—being watched while you do the thing versus presenting finished work. That's a really specific pattern. What do you think being visible exposes that finished work doesn't? Like, what's the fear underneath "being seen doing the work"?

**Sabbatical anxiety shifting from "should I" to "what if it doesn't work":** Now that it's actually possible, the questions changed. That makes sense. When it was abstract, you could debate responsibility and affordability. Now it's real, and your brain is hunting for new reasons to be afraid: what if I don't want to change anything, what if I've been running from the wrong thing. Those are harder questions because they don't have answers yet—you can't know until you're in it.

But let me ask you this: what if you spend three months and come out realizing you *don't* want to change careers, but you understand yourself better and come back to the same work with less exhaustion? Is that a waste? Or what if you realize you've been running from the wrong thing—like, what if the thing you've been trying to escape isn't the job itself but the voice that tells you you're fooling everyone? Would that be useful to know?

Things are shifting. You're right that it's hard to tell if it's progress or just different problems. But different problems means you're not stuck in the same loop anymore.

exchanges.user:
Been a weird week, honestly. The sabbatical thing feels more real now—we're actually looking at dates, talking to a financial planner next month. Which should feel good, I guess, but mostly I'm just anxious in a different way. Like we've crossed some threshold and now there's actual accountability.

Work's been fine. Quiet, almost. Which is its own thing—I keep waiting for something to go wrong just to confirm the baseline anxiety I'm carrying around. That probably sounds dramatic.

But here's what's actually been sitting with me since our last conversation. You asked what being visible exposes that finished work doesn't. And I've been thinking about it constantly, and I think... it's the uncertainty? Like when I'm heads down working, I'm inside the process. I know what I'm doing, why I'm doing it. But when I'm in a meeting, throwing an idea out there, suddenly people are watching me *think* in real time. And thinking in real time means I might be wrong, or unclear, or contradicting myself. There's no buffer between the messy process and how people perceive me.

Which is obvious when I say it, but I think that's actually the thing. Not that I'm worried I'm incompetent—it's that I'm worried people will *see* the incompetence in the process. That they'll watch me struggle with something and decide that means I'm struggling in general.

Anyway. That's been the thing I can't shake. And then yesterday my manager asked me to lead a workshop next month on the system redesign I did two years ago—the one I've been minimizing as "just timing." So apparently other people don't see it that way. But now I have to actually stand in front of people and talk about my own work without making it sound like I had nothing to do with it, which feels... complicated.
exchanges.assistant:
**The sabbatical timeline getting real:** Crossed some threshold—yeah, that's exactly what happened. When it was theoretical, you could debate it. Now you're talking to a financial planner, picking dates, and there's actual accountability. That shift from "should I?" to "okay, this is happening" brings a different kind of anxiety because now you're committed to finding out what's on the other side. The part of you that's anxious isn't irrational—it's anticipating that you'll actually have to sit with yourself for three months without the distraction of the grind. What do you think you're most worried you'll discover?

**Waiting for something to go wrong at work:** You said it probably sounds dramatic, but I don't think it does. When you're carrying baseline anxiety, quiet feels suspicious. Your nervous system is primed for threat, so when there's no visible threat, it starts scanning harder. That's not dramatic—that's just how hypervigilance works. It doesn't know how to rest.

**What being visible exposes—the messy process:** You landed on something really precise here. It's not that you doubt your competence when you're heads down—it's that in meetings, people are watching you *think in real time*, and thinking in real time is messy. You might be wrong, unclear, contradict yourself. There's no buffer between the uncertain process and their perception of you. And the fear is that if they see you struggle with something, they'll decide you're struggling in general.

Here's what I'm curious about: when you watch other people think in real time in meetings—when they're unclear or backtrack or get pushed back on—what do you think about them? Do you decide they're incompetent in general? Or do you just see it as part of working through an idea? Because I'm guessing you extend way more generosity to other people's messy process than you do to your own.

**The workshop on your system redesign:** This is a perfect test case for everything we've been talking about. Your manager didn't ask you to lead this workshop because of good timing—they asked because you designed something that worked and other people want to learn from it. But now you're in the exact situation you've been describing: you have to stand in front of people and talk about your own work without deflecting credit. That feels complicated because the deflection has been your safety move. If you don't take credit, you can't be exposed as a fraud.

So here's the question: what would it look like to talk about that project honestly—acknowledging the good timing AND your decisions, the team you built AND the leadership you provided? Not puffing yourself up, just... telling the truth about what you actually did?

exchanges.user:
So I've been sitting with what you asked about how I treat other people's messy thinking versus my own, and honestly it stung a little because the answer is obvious. I give everyone else a ton of grace. My colleague can backtrack in a meeting and I don't think twice about it. But when I do the same thing, I'm replaying it for hours convinced I've revealed something fundamental about myself.

The workshop thing though—that's what's actually been eating at me. I've been trying to prepare for it, and I keep getting stuck on how to talk about the project without either taking full credit (which feels wrong and grandiose) or immediately hedging it into oblivion (which is what I usually do). There's this middle ground I'm supposed to find where I acknowledge what I actually did without making it sound like I walked on water, and I genuinely don't know how to inhabit that space.

I tried drafting an outline yesterday and found myself writing these sentences like "the team was instrumental" and "timing certainly helped" and I just... stopped. Because yeah, the team was important, and timing did matter, but I also made specific design decisions that shaped how the whole thing worked. And I'm pretty sure I can say both things without one canceling out the other. Intellectually I get that. But sitting down to actually prepare to say it in front of thirty people is different.

Also—kind of random but also maybe not—I had another moment with my wife where I mentioned the workshop and she just said, "You're going to kill it. You know this stuff inside and out." And I wanted to believe her but my first instinct was to think she's just being supportive because she's my wife. Which is probably unfair to her. She's not lying to make me feel better. She's just stating what she actually thinks. Why is that so hard to take at face value?
exchanges.assistant:
**The double standard you caught:** Yeah, it stings because it's true. You give your colleague infinite grace for backtracking—you see it as normal thinking-out-loud—but when you do it, it becomes evidence of something fundamentally wrong with you. That's not a small observation. That's the core of the hypervigilance we've been tracking: other people get to be human in real time, but you're holding yourself to a standard where messy thinking = exposure. What would it be like to extend yourself even half the grace you give your colleague? Not as a feel-good exercise, but as an actual experiment: next time you backtrack in a meeting, notice the urge to replay it, and then ask yourself, "Would I judge [colleague's name] for this?" and see what happens.

**The workshop outline—that middle ground you can't find:** You're stuck because you're treating "I made specific design decisions that shaped the whole thing" and "the team was instrumental, timing helped" like they're in competition. They're not. Both are true. The project succeeded because you made good calls *and* because you had a strong team *and* because the timing worked. But here's what I'm noticing: when you write "the team was instrumental," that's easy. When you write "I made specific design decisions that shaped how the whole thing worked," you stop. Why? What happens in your body or your mind when you start to claim your actual contribution?

Here's a frame that might help: your job in this workshop isn't to be humble or impressive. It's to teach people what you learned. And you can't teach them what you learned if you scrub yourself out of the story. What were the specific design decisions you made? What were you thinking when you made them? What would have happened if you'd chosen differently? Those are the parts people actually need to hear—not because it's about you, but because that's where the learning is.

**Your wife saying you'll kill it:** Your first instinct was to dismiss it as supportive-spouse talk instead of her actual assessment. That's the same move as deflecting credit for the system redesign—if you don't let her opinion count, you don't have to sit with the possibility that she's right. But she's not just being nice. She lives with you. She sees what you're capable of. She knows you know this stuff inside and out. What makes her wrong? And more importantly: what's scary about believing her?

exchanges.user:
Okay so I did the workshop yesterday and I need to process it because it's sitting with me in a way I didn't expect.

I went in with the outline I'd been wrestling with—the one where I was trying to figure out how to claim my work without sounding grandiose. And honestly, I was still anxious walking in. Like, that baseline waiting-for-something-to-go-wrong feeling. But then something shifted once I actually started talking. I stopped reading the script version in my head and just... talked about what I'd actually done. The thinking process, the specific choices, why I made them. And people were engaged. They asked questions. One person even said afterward that hearing the reasoning behind the decisions was what made it useful, not just the final outcome.

The thing that's weird is I don't think I was more confident than usual. I was still nervous. But I was nervous while actually doing the thing instead of nervous about what people might think while I was doing the thing. Does that make sense? Like the anxiety didn't disappear, it just changed shape.

But here's what's been bugging me since: I kept waiting for that hot flush of shame when I talked about my role in the design work. And it didn't come. Or it came and I just... kept talking anyway. And I'm wondering if that means something actually shifted, or if it was just adrenaline and I'm going to wake up tomorrow and feel like an idiot for having been so direct about what I contributed.

Also—and this might be nothing—but my wife's comment about knowing I know this stuff inside and out kept coming back to me during the workshop. Like I could hear her saying it while I was standing there. Which sounds hokey when I write it out, but it actually mattered. It gave me something to hold onto.

The sabbatical timeline is getting closer too. We're looking at late spring now. Part of me still thinks it's irresponsible, but another part of me is realizing that might just be the voice that tells me I'm a fraud, and maybe I shouldn't trust everything that voice says.
exchanges.assistant:
**The workshop—what actually happened:** You walked in anxious, stopped performing the script in your head, and just talked about what you'd actually done. People were engaged. Someone specifically said the *reasoning* behind your decisions was what made it useful. That's not a small thing. You were afraid that claiming your work would sound grandiose, but what you discovered is that when you talk about your actual thinking process—the choices, the why—it's not grandiose. It's teaching. And people wanted to learn from it.

The shift you're describing—nervous *while doing the thing* instead of nervous *about what people might think*—yeah, that makes complete sense. The first kind of nervous is just activation, energy your body needs to show up and perform. The second kind is the hypervigilance we've been tracking, the part that's scanning for judgment and threat. You were still anxious, but you weren't stuck in the meta-layer of watching yourself and evaluating how you were coming across. That's a real shift.

**Waiting for the shame that didn't come:** You kept waiting for that hot flush when you talked about your role in the design work, and it either didn't come or you kept talking anyway. I don't think that's adrenaline. I think that's what happens when you stop pre-emptively deflecting and just tell the truth about what you did. The shame response is conditioned—it fires when you believe that claiming your work will expose you as a fraud. But you weren't claiming to be perfect or omniscient. You were just describing the decisions you made and why you made them. There's nothing fraudulent about that. Your nervous system is starting to learn that.

Now, will you wake up tomorrow feeling like an idiot for being so direct? Maybe. That's the old pattern reasserting itself. But here's the thing: even if that voice shows up tomorrow, you now have evidence that it's not the whole truth. Thirty people engaged with your workshop. Someone told you the reasoning was the valuable part. Your wife was right when she said you know this stuff inside and out. That happened. The self-doubt might come back, but it doesn't erase what actually occurred.

**Your wife's voice during the workshop:** That's not hokey. That's what secure attachment does—it gives you something to hold onto when your own voice isn't enough. She believes in your competence, and in that moment, you let yourself borrow her belief until you could find your own footing. That's not weakness. That's using the resources you have.

**The sabbatical timeline and the fraud voice:** Late spring. Getting real. And you're catching that the "this is irresponsible" voice might be the same voice that tells you you're a fraud—the one that scans for threat, that assumes you're fooling everyone, that won't let you take credit. That voice has been trying to keep you safe by keeping you small. But what if you don't have to trust everything it says? What if you can hear it, acknowledge it's trying to protect you, and then make a different choice anyway?

What are you most curious about for those three months? Not what you're afraid of—what you actually want to find out.

exchanges.user:
Been a few days since the workshop and I keep circling back to it, which I know probably means something. The high from it wore off pretty quick, if I'm being honest. By the next morning I was already doing the thing where I'm like "okay but did I actually say anything useful or did people just sit there being polite." Which I recognize is the pattern you've been pointing out, so at least I can see it happening now instead of just believing it wholesale.

But something's different this time. Usually when I catch myself doing that, I just spiral deeper. This time I actually did what you suggested—I asked myself whether I'd judge a colleague for giving that workshop the same way I'm judging myself. And the answer was no. Obviously not. My colleague would've done a solid job and I would've thought it was useful and moved on. So why am I not allowed the same basic courtesy?

I haven't figured that out yet. But sitting with the question instead of dismissing it felt like something.

The other thing is my wife brought up the sabbatical again, and we're actually starting to tell people. Which is weird because suddenly it's not just our internal conversation anymore. It's real and external and other people have opinions about it. My boss was actually really supportive when I mentioned we were exploring options, which I did not expect. But of course my brain immediately went to "he only said that because he thinks I'm about to burn out and he's glad to get ahead of it," instead of just taking it at face value that maybe he respects me and wants me to figure out what I actually want.

I'm doing that thing a lot lately where I'm assigning motivations to people that make them less supportive than they actually are. It's exhausting. And I think it's the same root as everything else—if people are just being nice because they pity me or want to manage me, then their support doesn't actually mean anything about my competence. Which keeps me safe from having to actually believe I'm capable.

Anyway. Spring's coming. Feels surreal.
exchanges.assistant:
**Catching the pattern in real time:** You're not just seeing it anymore—you're actually doing something different with it. That's huge. Usually the spiral just happens and you're in it. This time you caught yourself doing the "were they just being polite" thing, and instead of following that thought all the way down, you actually tested it against reality. You asked whether you'd judge a colleague the same way. The answer was no, obviously not. And then you asked the harder question: why aren't you allowed the same basic courtesy? That's not a small shift. You're starting to see the double standard as a choice you're making, not just a fact about how things are.

You said you haven't figured out why yet, and that's okay. Sitting with the question instead of dismissing it is the work. The answer will come.

**Your boss's response to the sabbatical:** He was supportive, and your brain immediately turned it into "he thinks I'm about to burn out and wants to manage the situation" instead of "maybe he respects me and wants me to figure out what I want." Same pattern, different context. You're assigning motivations that make people's support mean less so you don't have to sit with the possibility that they actually see you as capable. That's the protection mechanism we've been tracking—if their support is just pity or damage control, then you don't have to believe it reflects anything real about your competence.
